column2: Which specific factors inform your views about the privacy of [online exam proctoring service name].
no camera
Lockdown alone is not a concern. The only concern is if we used cameras as well.
I did not pay much attention to this
Don't know much about it - only use it b/c it was associated with a current product we use.
Monitoring implies that we think students will cheat and that sounds like guilty until proven innocent

Most digital tools have some level of privacy issues. Any program that can access an internal mic or video seems to be a privacy risk. There are other learning tools such as Voice thread that I believe have a privacy risk but see the benefit outweighing the risk and damage to the student.
Students must show their full surroundings, which can be awkward but necessary
We need to ensure the data from the 3rd party vendors are deleted and verified.

We're being constantly recorded on a daily basis - from Alexa listening in our homes to security cameras on all sorts of buildings. I don't really see it as an invasion of privacy, but that's just me.

Any program that requires you to download a file, disables your system functionality, and automatically searches your computer for files to upload is a total invasion of privacy. Additionally, the proctoring service records the student at their most vulnerable- in their home environment where they sometimes forget they are being recorded. This leaves the potential for private matters being recorded and permanently on a server somewhere... if there is a data breach of this program, these videos could be out there for anyone to see.
It is not easy to prove the cheating when the exam is online,.. there are some patterns but not perfect -- so cannot accuse a student of cheating when there is not clear evidence
Adaptability and customization. You don't have to utilize all tools (i.e. webcam) and I didn't. Instead, I just used the browser lockdown.
Have no idea how secure it it.
"Glad to see the tradeoff question: Yes, it is somewhat invasive but that is offset by exam integrity."

We frequently use Zoom (or similar tools) for all kinds of meetings, and most people appreciate the convenience of being able to do so. I don't perceive an exam scenario as having different privacy concerns than any other use of such virtual conferencing tools.
"AI required to monitor and flag student behavior use of recordings in private setting"
Privacy
Experience
Not worth the risks to me. I would not feel confident making an accusation of cheating based on this software.
I have taken exams as a student under RPNow and used it as an instructor.
The ineffectiveness of Respondus is the issue, not the privacy.
The longterm storage of recordings.
I have no opinion on this
Unknown

Students are monitored if taking in person exam, so I don't see the difference between monitored at home or in class. If students are concerned about the videos being used later on without their consent, they can make a request for the videos to be deleted.
Video monitoring is more intrusive
